title: Instructor
tasks: Teach a 2-unit, 10-week course exploring the Python programming language with an emphasis on building core capability with the language and using Python for machine learning and data science.
Design and deliver course curriculum including lectures, handouts, reading materials, assignments, labs, and more.

title: Law Clerk for the Gang Crimes Unit
tasks: Conducted legal research and composed memorandum about incredibly exigent issues involving, e.g., the constitutionality of cell-site location information and investigative alerts, etc.
Interviewed witnesses and prepared them for trial.
Conducted research and performed stand-by duties in People v. Jovan Battle, involving the murder of an off-duty police officer.

title: Teaching Assistant for CS 106
tasks: Teach a group of ~10 students in a discussion section for the introductory computer science class at Stanford, one of the largest undergraduate classes at the university.
Grade weekly assignments for the class.

title: Intern
company: Office of the District Attorney of Brazos County
tasks: Conducted a statistical analysis of crime in Brazos County by implementing machine learning algorithms in Python to analyze big data sets. The analysis improved the office policy regarding domestic violence and burglary cases.
Reviewed numerous of cases during the intake phase to determine whether they should be presented to a Grand Jury for indictment by looking for constitutional violations by officers and other issues.
Assisted with jury selection in five cases in district courts in Brazos County.
Visited witnesses and took notes on their planned testimony.

title: Undergraduate Researcher
description:
Worked under Dr. J. M. Landsberg on a problem that lies at the intersection of algebraic geometry and combinatorics. The project studies the geometry of tensor networks. This is a question which has applications in quantum information theory and computer science.
See the paper I wrote at https://arxiv.org/abs/1806.03567.
